task: Select an element by its order in another element
description_task: Selects <mark>nth</mark> () child element in another element.
example_first: <mark>:nth-child(6)</mark>selects every element that is the 8th child of another element.
example_second: <mark>div p:nth-child(5)</mark> selects the second p in every <mark>div</mark>

description_task: This selects all elements inside of <mark>A</mark>
example_first: <mark>p *</mark> selects every element inside all <mark><p></mark> elements.
example_second: <mark>ul.fancy *</mark> selects every element inside all <mark><ul class="eating"></mark>

description_task: Thanks to Shatner technology, this selects all <mark>A</mark> and <mark>B</mark> elements. You can combine any selectors this way, and you can specify more than two.
example_first: <mark>p .good</mark> selects all <mark><p></mark> elements as well as all elements with <mark>class="good"</mark>.
example_second: <mark>a, p, div</mark> selects all <mark><a></mark>, <mark><p></mark> and <mark><div></mark> elements

description_task: You can select all elements with the universal selector!
example_first: <mark>p *</mark> selects any element inside all <mark><p></mark> elements

task: Select an element inside another element
description_task: Selects all B inside of A. B is called a descendant because it is inside of another element.
example_first: <mark>p strong</mark> selects all <mark><strong></mark> elements that are inside of any <mark><p></mark>.
example_second: <mark>#fancy span</mark> selects any span elements that are inside of the element with <mark>id="fancy"</mark>

task: Select elements that follows another element
description_task: You can select all siblings of an element that follow it. This is like the Adjacent Selector (A + B) except it gets all of the following elements instead of one.
example_first: <mark>A ~ B</mark> selects all <mark><B></mark> that follow a <mark><A></mark>.
